bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, April 9, 1923

div1.p: Connor discusses a test for the diagnosis of yellow fever and the possibility of combining an anti-malarial campaign with yellow fever work. He suggests that the Board employ someone to study paleo-pathology.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, April 9, 1923
div1.p:
I H B
Merida, Yucatan, Mexico.
April 9th., 1 9 2 3. PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
ESTADOS UNIDOS MEXICANOS
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA DE MEXICO
----
JEFATURA DE LA CAMPAÑA CONTRA
LA FIEBRE AMARILLA EN YUCATAN
----
MERIDA, YUC., MEX.
Connor
Answered in detail May 20/23
I. H. B
My dear Doctor Carter;

Your very welcome letter of March of 11th., ult.
was here in Merida on my arrival April 3rd., I do appreciate
all the trouble that you have been put to in answering my
last long letter.

I am hoping that the Pfiffier reaction will prove to be
of value as border line cases will be constantly coming up
for decision more especially in the Gulf Coast region and it
means that in the absence of some definite or fairly definite test
we will continue to have yellow fever diagnosed and our work never
finished.

In my last talk with Doctor White I suggessted the advisa-
bility or wisdom of doing anti-malaria work in connection with
our yellow fever campaign. It has been done in some places and
in these localities borderline cases have been eliminated. I wish
that our Board were contemplating an anti-malaria campaign in Mexico
in stead of a hookworm campaign.

Speaking about the Habana school, has Dr. Guiteras re-
signed from the yellow fever council? On the last letter head recently
received from Doctor White his name did not appear.

Further experiments with lejia (agua cenizas) show that our
best hope with this class of containers is in the direction of de-
veloping a copper container or else soldering or riveting a piece of
copper plate to the ordinary container. It is difficult to change
the habits of long standing in a few months and this ex-
plains why the pieces of copper plate suelto are not as sucessful as the
might be. The orange or lime peel is being more generally used and
in time there use will increase. Wherevever used they are appear to be
successful. The copper paint, one coat, does not last long, the
alkaline solution dissolves it off the tin. The action of the copper
and orange or lime peel is purely that of a repellant. It will not
kill larve already in the receptacle but will prevent the adult from de-
positing eggs.

I will be glad and consider it a great honor to review
the history which you have in preparation. My address until Doctor
White returns to Mexico will be Calle Constitucion #13, Vera Cruz, Ver.
The foregoing will be my headquarters while on this general in-
specting detail.

It is Mr. Martinez, but we all call him Doctor, as far as I know he carries no
titles but as you say he should. He appears to me to be a genuine scientist
in his special line, Maya Antiguities and is imposed upon by nearly every archeolog-
ist that comes here but he rarely says a word against them but never for-
gets to eulogize those that have been kind to him and this explains in part why he
is ever anxious to aid you.

I have just come across an old work on yellow fever, perhaps you have it, the t
title page is next attached. Should you care to see it I feel quite that same
arrangements might be made to send it to you. Dr. Roman Sebas Flores has it, and
his address is Calle 58 #497 Merida, Yucatan, Mexico. The work is in the
main historical and an attempt to establish a separate entity for yellow fever in
Spain.

The two big mistakes that have been made in Mexico are; 1st. The Comision form of
organization for supervison of the work with the Director in the early days of
the campaign outside the country a large part of the time, and 2nd: our mis-
conception of what constituted a key center or area in Mexico in the first year of
the campaign. Through this misconception we were lured, as it were, into a false
sense of security and from which we were rudely shaken in time to
apply the knowledge gained, what a calamity it would have been had we been out
of the country when the ‘bubble burst’. I am going to try and reduce our ex-
perience here to writing for the convention this fall.

Regarding the legend as to the freedom of San Juan Bautista noew Villa-
hermosa from Yellow fever there does seem to be a story that that city was free
and had been free from many years. It will have to be verified by going to the
town which I propose to do in June and possibly before if it can be arranged.
In the meantime am sending out in quiries to medicos who should have some know-
ledge of the history of yellow fever in Tabasco.

The only village that I know of being free of stegomyia mosquitos was Zacamixtle
an oil town of about 2000 inhabitants. It was free during LePrinces time in Mexico
but recently Scannell states that he found Aedes Egyptus there, unfortunately his
findings were not submitted to experts which should have been done in the interest
of history. No doubt Scannell did find the ‘legitimos’ and they should have been
Zacamixtle long before as there had been a constant stream of people moving into
this area from ‘steg’ infested regions and it would have been the easiest thing in
the world to have carried larvae along with them, but I wish they had been identi-
fied as by this time they have all been destroyed. I will make it a point to go to
Zacamixtle to see what present conditions are. Drop a line to Scannel re This
I saw Morely and Spinden. The former is in Mexico City trying to arrange for a
concession to reconstruct Chichen Itza. Spinden is back in the states and at work I believe
on an article showing the march of syphilis and other diseases that have taken a
part in the ‘rise and fall of civilizations’.

It has occured to me of late that our Board should be interested in paleopatholo
gy and we might learn something of interest if detail a man to work with the arch
eologists in their researches. There undoubtedly would be some surprising findings
that would help us in our present day worK.

Referring to the term ‘endemic’, it seems to me that this word carries the
same meaning to yellow fever as it does to other diseases and something more, be-
cause yellow fever is not a carrying disease in the sense that other infections are,
yellow fever is in every truly a self-limited infection and the sub-divisions ‘tem-
porarily’ and ‘permanently’ endemic accurately describes the condition, a time element
might be worked out to show when ‘temporarily’ becomes ‘permanently’.

Am now collecting data with the thought of reducing to a formula the time necess
ary for mosquito index (‘Aedes’) to rise from five to ten percent, and if of practic
able service it ought to effect a saving in adminstration.

as ever your friend
M E Connor
